problem:
\begin{problem*}{}{}
  Let $a_1$, $a_2$, \ldots, $a_n$ be positive reals and let
  \[
    m=\min\left\{a_1+\frac1{a_2},
    a_2+\frac1{a_3},\ldots,a_n+\frac1{a_1}\right\}.
  \]
  Show that
  \[
    \sqrt[n]{a_1a_2\cdots a_n}
    +\frac1{\sqrt[n]{a_1a_2\cdots a_n}}\ge m.
  \]
\end{problem*}
solution:
\begin{soln}
  Let
  \[
    G=\sqrt[n]{a_1a_2\cdots a_n},
  \]
  and let $k$ be the index such that
  \[
    a_k=\min_{1\le i\le n}\{a_i\}.
  \]
  So, $G\ge a_k$. If $G\le a_{k+1}$, then
  \[
    G+\frac1G\ge a_k+\frac1{a_{k+1}}\ge m.
  \]

  Otherwise $G>a_{k+1}$. Similarly, we can continue using this
  pattern until we reach an index $j$ such that
  \[
    G\ge a_j\quad\text{and}\quad G\le a_{j+1}.
  \]
  If no such index exists, then $G>a_i$ for all $1\le i\le n$,
  which implies
  \[
    nG>\sum_{i=1}^n a_i\ge nG,
  \]
  where the last inequality follows by AMâ€“GM.
  This however is a clear contradiction and hence,
  such an index $j$ must exist and we are done.
\end{soln}
